Sau đó, anh tiếp tục giúp đỡ những người khác trong gia tộc, cung cấp cho họ thức ăn, nước uống và nơi ở. Anh cũng giúp họ tìm kiếm công việc và hỗ trợ họ trong việc xây dựng lại nhà cửa. La oscuridad que se cernía sobre la habitación parecía ser un reflejo de la oscuridad que se había apoderado de su corazón. Intentó recordar el sonido de su risa, la forma en que sus ojos brillaban cuando sonreía, pero todo lo que logró fue sentir una gran tristeza que la envolvía como una manta fría. La música, que había sido su refugio, ahora parecía ser un recordatorio constante de lo que había perdido. La noche avanzaba y ella seguía sentada en la oscuridad, rodeada de la música que había compartido con Willoughby, pero sin él, sin su presencia, sin su amor. La soledad la envolvía como un manto negro y pesado, y no sabía si podría encontrar la fuerza para seguir adelante sin él.

en_first_half: Amongst the objects in the scene, they soon discovered an animated one; it was a man on horseback riding towards
en_second_half: them. In a few minutes they could distinguish him to be a gentleman; and in a moment afterwards Marianne rapturously exclaimed,
en_results: The group of travelers, who had been walking through the dense forest for hours, were shocked to see the man on horseback riding
en_results_raw: The group of travelers, who had been walking through the dense forest for hours, were shocked to see the man on horseback riding towards them with a determined look on his face. As he drew closer, they noticed that he was dressed in worn leather armor and carried a longsword at his side, which seemed to be his only visible weapon. The man's horse, a majestic black stallion, was also well-groomed and seemed to be in top condition, indicating that its rider was a skilled horseman. The travelers exchanged nervous glances, unsure of what to expect from this mysterious figure, but they stood their ground, ready to face whatever lay ahead. As the man approached, he slowed his horse to a stop in front of them, and for a moment, the only sound was the heavy breathing of the horse and the rustling of leaves in the gentle breeze. The man's eyes scanned the group, taking in their appearance, and then his gaze settled on the leader, a tall, burly man with a thick beard, who stood at the front of the group. The man's expression changed from one of caution to one of surprise, and he dismounted his horse, his movements fluid and deliberate. He approached the group, his eyes never leaving the bearded man's face, and spoke in a deep, resonant voice, "I am Eryndor Thorne, a traveler from a nearby village, and I must say, I am not pleased to see you all here. What brings you to these woods?" The bearded man, whose name was Grimbold, stepped forward, his hand on the hilt of his sword, and replied, "We are on a quest to reach the ancient ruins of the long-lost city of Eldarath, said to be hidden deep within these woods. We have been searching for weeks, but we have encountered many dangers along the way." Eryndor's expression turned from surprise to interest, and he nodded thoughtfully, "Ah, you must be the ones I've heard rumors of. I too, have been searching for Eldarath, but I have been searching for a different reason. I am on a quest to find the fabled Sword of Light, said to be hidden within the ruins. It is said to have the power to vanquish any darkness, and I believe it is the key to saving my village from the dark forces that threaten to consume it." Grimbold's eyes widened in surprise, and he looked at Eryndor with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion, "The Sword of Light, you say? I had not heard of that. But I must warn you, the ruins are said to be treacherous, filled with ancient traps and creatures that will stop at nothing to keep the ruins and its secrets safe. Are you sure you're prepared for what lies ahead?" Eryndor nodded resolutely, "I have been preparing for this moment for years, and I am not one to back down from a challenge. But I must ask, have you heard anything about the layout of the ruins? Any information would be greatly appreciated." Grimbold hesitated for a moment, then replied, "I have heard that the ruins are divided into three main sections: the Temple of the Ancients, the Hall of the Elements, and the Chamber of the Ancients. But I have also heard that the ruins are guarded by a powerful entity, one that will not give up its secrets easily. We will need to be careful if we are to succeed in our quest." Eryndor's eyes lit up with excitement, and he nodded eagerly, "Thank you, Grimbold. Your information is invaluable. I think we can work together to achieve our goals. But first, let us get to know each other better. What brings you and your group to these woods?" As the two men began to talk, the rest of the group exchanged nervous glances, unsure of what to make of this unexpected turn of events. But as they listened to Eryndor and Grimbold's conversation, they began to realize that they had stumbled upon something much bigger than themselves, something that could change the course of their lives forever.

en_second_half: they, the season, the air altogether inspired! Now there is no one to regard them. They are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as possible from the sight."
en_results: arise within me of a more lively kind from the view of these beautiful autumnal scenes! The fluttering leaves, the rustling of the branches, the soft whispers of the trees as they sway
en_results_raw: arise within me of a more lively kind from the view of these beautiful autumnal scenes! The fluttering leaves, the rustling of the branches, the soft whispers of the trees as they sway gently in the breeze, all combined to fill my heart with a sense of joy and contentment. And yet, as I stood there, lost in the beauty of nature, I couldn't help but feel a pang of melancholy, a sense of the fleeting nature of these moments, the transience of life itself. The leaves, so full of life and color just a moment before, now lay scattered at my feet, their vibrant hues muted and faded, a reminder that all things must come to an end. But even in death, there is beauty, a beauty that speaks to the cycle of life, the ebb and flow of existence. And so, I stood there, surrounded by the remnants of the autumnal storm, feeling the wind in my hair, the sun on my face, and the peace that comes from being a part of something greater than myself.

Mientras tanto, el hombre se levantó de su asiento y se acercó a la ventana, mirando hacia fuera, lo que le dio a Elinor la oportunidad de observarlo de cerca y tratar de descubrir qué era lo que estaba ocultando. But in my opinion, it is a very different thing to have a taste for the picturesque, and to be able to describe it in a manner that is at all satisfactory. I have been in the company of many people who have professed to be great admirers of nature, and yet, when we were out walking together, they would hardly notice the most striking features of the landscape, or, if they did, they would describe them in a way that was so clumsy and ungrammatical, that it was quite painful to listen to. I must confess, I have always been particularly fond of the works of Mr. Uvedale, who has written so eloquently about the beauty of the English countryside, and the way in which it can be improved by the judicious placement of trees and other features. His descriptions are not only beautiful, but they are also full of practical advice, which makes them particularly useful to anyone who is interested in landscape gardening. But, I must say, that I have also come across many people who, while they may have a good eye for the picturesque, are not able to express their thoughts in a clear and concise manner, and so, their descriptions are often confusing and difficult to follow. In my opinion, it is a great pity that more people do not take the time to learn how to describe what they see, as it would not only make their descriptions more enjoyable to read, but it would also allow them to share their love of nature with others in a more effective way.

en_results: It was a habit he had formed on their first acquaintance, and one which, though it had originally arisen from a consideration rather too much for his own dignity, was now
en_results_raw: It was a habit he had formed on their first acquaintance, and one which, though it had originally arisen from a consideration rather too much for his own dignity, was now continued and even increased, from its being no longer disagreeable to him. He had, in fact, grown so accustomed to the pleasure of their company, that he could hardly bear to be without it for a single day. The Dashwoods, on their part, were equally pleased with the arrangement, and never failed to accept his invitations with alacrity. They had, in fact, grown so fond of Sir John's hospitality, that they would have been truly distressed if they had been unable to join him at least once a week. The evenings spent at the park were always lively and enjoyable, and the Dashwoods looked forward to them with great anticipation, knowing that they would be treated to good food, good company, and good conversation. Sir John's table was always well-stocked with an assortment of delicacies, and his wines were of the finest quality. The Dashwoods had never known a more pleasant or more sociable host, and they were grateful for the many happy hours they had spent in his company.

en_results_raw: be no more than a mere abstraction; and she was not disposed to make the attempt. Her feelings were too deeply rooted in her nature; and she could not help being guided by them, even when she wished to be otherwise. In this state of mind, she was not disposed to be severe with others, who, like herself, were the slaves of their emotions; and she could not but think that Colonel Brandon's reserve was, in a great measure, to be excused by the same consideration. His reserve, indeed, was not the only peculiarity in his character, which she had discovered since her acquaintance with him; and she could not help feeling a little surprised, that a man so quiet and unassuming, should have been the object of such strong attachment in the past, as his sister, Elinor, had described. But, as she reflected on the subject, she began to suspect, that there might be more in Colonel Brandon's reserve, than mere reserve; and that, perhaps, he was not so entirely free from the influence of his own emotions, as he appeared to be. She could not help feeling a little interested in the mystery, and she was determined to learn more about it, if possible. And so, she made up her mind to ask Elinor, if she knew anything about Colonel Brandon's past, and what had caused him to be so reserved. She was not sure, however, that Elinor would be willing to tell her, and she was prepared for a refusal. But, she was determined to try, and to see if she could get any information out of her sister, about the mysterious Colonel Brandon.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.

Mary đã đến để thăm gia đình họ để giúp đỡ trong việc quản lý gia đình sau khi cha của Fanny qua đời. Tuy nhiên, Fanny không thể giúp đỡ Mary trong việc quản lý gia đình, vì cô không thể chịu được áp lực và áp đặt của người chị mình. It was on a visit to a relation of ours, a Mr. Brandon, who lives in a small cottage on the outskirts of the village. His daughter, a young woman of about my own age, had been ill for some time, and I had gone to visit her with my mother. As we were sitting in the garden, I overheard a conversation between Mr. Brandon and his daughter, which made me realize that they were not as they seemed. They were talking about a secret, and I could tell that it was something important, something that they did not want anyone else to know. I felt a pang of curiosity, and I must admit that I was tempted to eavesdrop further, but I knew it would be wrong, so I excused myself and left the garden, feeling a little guilty but also a little relieved that I had not given in to my curiosity. My mother, however, seemed to sense that something was amiss, and she asked me if I had heard anything unusual. I told her that I had not, but I could see that she was not convinced. She seemed to be thinking about something, and I could tell that she was trying to make sense of it all. I did not press her for more information, but I could not help but wonder what was going on. As we left the cottage, I couldn't shake the feeling that we had stumbled upon something much bigger than we could have ever imagined.

en_first_half: "Edward talks of going to Oxford soon," said she; "but now he is lodging at No. —, Pall Mall. What an ill–natured woman his mother is, an't she? And for my part, I was all in a fright for fear your sister should ask us for the huswifes she had gave us a day or two before; but, however, nothing was said about them, and I took care to keep mine out of sight. en_second_half: business at Oxford, he says; so he must go there for a time; and after THAT, as soon as he can light upon a Bishop, he will be ordained. es_first_half: —Edward habla de irse pronto a Oxford —dijo—, pero por el momento está alojado en el N°... de Pall Mall. Qué mala persona es su madre, ¿no? ¡Y su hermano y su cuñada tampoco fueron muy amables! Pero no le voy a hablar a usted en contra de ellos; y con todo, nos enviaron a casa en su propio carruaje, lo que fue más de lo que yo esperaba. Y por mi parte, yo estaba aterrada de que su cuñada fuera a pedir que le devolviéramos los acericos que nos había dado uno o dos días atrás; pero nada se dijo sobre ellos, y me cuidé de mantener el mío fuera
es_second_half: de la vista de los demás. Edward dice que tiene que arreglar algunos asuntos en Oxford, así que debe ir allá por un tiempo; y después, apenas consiga a un obispo, se ordenará. ¡Qué curiosidad me da saber qué parroquia le darán! ¡Dios bendito! —continuó con una risita tonta—, apostaría mi vida a que sé lo que dirán mis primas cuando lo sepan. Me dirán que le escriba al reverendo, para que le dé a Edward la parroquia de su nuevo beneficio. Sé que lo harán; pero le digo que por nada del mundo haría tal cosa. “¡Ay!”, les diré directamente, “como pueden pensar tal cosa. Yo escribirle al reverendo... ¡por favor!”

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."

es_first_half: —Sí, una vez, cuando estaba alojada en esta casa. Me había dejado caer por unos diez minutos, y me bastó con lo que vi de ella. Una simple muchacha pueblerina, desmañada, sin estilo ni elegancia, y casi sin ningún atractivo. La recuerdo perfectamente. Justo el tipo de muchacha que habría creído capaz de cautivar al pobre Edward. Apenas mi madre me contó todo el asunto, de inmediato me ofrecí— a hablarle, a disuadirlo de la unión; pero, según pude darme cuenta, ya era demasiado tarde para hacer algo, pues por desgracia no estuve ahí en los primeros momentos y no supe nada
es_second_half: de lo ocurrido hasta después de la ruptura, cuando, ya sabe usted, no me correspondía interferir. Pero si se me hubiera informado unas pocas horas antes, probablemente habría podido hacer algo. De todas maneras le habría hecho ver las cosas a Edward con toda claridad. “Mi querido amigo”, le habría dicho, “piensa en lo que haces. Estás comprometiéndote en la más desafortunada unión, que toda tu familia desaprueba de manera unánime”. En fin, no puedo evitar pensar que habría encontrado alguna manera de lograrlo. Pero ahora es demasiado tarde. Debe estar muerto de hambre, sabe usted; con toda seguridad, absolutamente muerto de hambre.
